[[File:Immunoglobulin basic unit.svg|thumb|
1. Fab region
2. Fc region
3. Heavy chain
4. Light chain with one variable (V L) and one constant
   (C L) domain
5. Fv region with paratope
6. Hinge regions]] The 'paratope' is the part of an antibody which recognizes an
   antigen, the antigen-binding site of an antibody. It is a small region (of
   15â22 amino acids) of the antibody's Fv region and contains parts of the
   antibody's heavy and light chains. }}

The part of the antigen to which the paratope binds is called an epitope. This
can be mimicked by a mimotope. The figure given on the right hand side depicts
the antibody commonly found on a B leukocyte. The engraved inner portions of
idiotype (encircled region no.5) is the paratope where the epitope of the
antigen binds.
